reviewText: WOW! Roberto Agagna is truly on top of his game in this Pagliacci! This was the very first time that I vigorously felt Canio's intense pain. I hadn't realized that Alagna has become such a strong, virile performer since the Tosca movie filmed in 2000. I saw Alagna recently on January 16, 2010, at the Live From The Met transmission of Carmen and this same virility emitted from him as Don Jose. Alagna presently is in as fine a voice as ever I've heard him. (I have several recordings.)  Svetia Vassileva was at home with herself as Nedda. I had never heard of her before but Svetia Vassileva was Nedda to the hilt, in build, temperament and, most especially vocally. I was only disappointed in Enrico Marrucci as Silvio. Silvio is a hard role to cast well. I'm fixated on the Silvio of Simon Keenlyside from a 2000 CD recording. A strong, charismatic Silvio is needed to be a convincing lover of the vibrant Nedda for her to risk her very life for love with this man of a much more placid temperament than the fiery Canio. THIS PAGLIACCI IS AS GOOD AS IT GETS!!!! I don't expect to see it surpassed any time soon. Buy it now.
Title: Leoncavallo - Pagliacci

reviewText: Alagna out sings himself in this glorious production of PAGLIACCI.  Now if he can keep the bar this high for all his other performances we've got another super star for the history books.  Svetia Vassileva catches on fire as Nedda and her leather outfit and sexy hat help matters along.  What a terrific performance.  Calling all opera lovers!  Buy this DVD!
Title: Leoncavallo - Pagliacci

reviewText: I was disappointed with this performance and the production. Too often, the camera gives us odd shots of the audience and the pit, which doesn't help draw you into the story.  Alagna can certainly act here, but his forced, high notes always go way sharp.  His Nedda, Svetla Vassileva, also gives it her best, but keeps sounding squally and strident. The best of the lot is the Tonio of baritone Alberto Mastromarino - both good acting and voice.  The sets and staging are befitting a standard college production.  Sound and visuals are fine, but I'd stick to the Domingo DVD for a hair-raising show.
Title: Leoncavallo - Pagliacci

reviewText: There's no wonder Leoncavallo's Pagliacci is still an all time favorite.  It pretty much strikes a chord with any of us who ever had someone dump us...and haven't we all? It is one of the most gut wrenching experiences for any mortal. How we handle it is the key- whether we pull our miserable selves together, or wind up in the hoosegow, or worse.This opera is enormously difficult to  manage for every player in it. the moods are mercurial; and so is the unforgettable score. It makes baroque chamber music seem positively somnambulistic by comparison.Roberto alagna, again, does not fail to excel. Nor does his supporting cast - all with diffucult, yet chillingly beautiful arias. I didn't think anyone could top Juan Pons sonorous prologue from the well known production with Placido  Domingo, but Mastromarino makes a fine Tonio.Speaking of Placido Domingo in the Zeferelli film of this same opera, we can't help but compare, can we? It is like comparing cantelopes with mangos. These are two different takes on this great opera, and is well worth owning both, or at least seeing both...and more versions too.I've read many of the  others reviewers' great reviews, and occasionally I hear some minor complaints about the supporting cast...the throng...there is an official italian word for it, I've forgotten now...but if any flaw can find its way into a production, it is in moving the chorus around in a plausible manner. Here they were not. They are a little wooden and self conscious. In truth, I suppose most of would feel terribly self conscious, making halting steps where we should be making bold strides, and realistic gestures. I don't mean to pan the stage director, but this was too much for that individual. It added a dose of awkwardness to the show that it should not have had at all. I believe the vocalists were affected by it; because it took some time for them to find their footing. It did start to come together in the second act. and that's good. It may not have come together at all, save for Roberto's magnificent interpretation of the beloved "Vesti La Giubba". You too will be comparing, to other performers you have seen or heard...but I adjure one and all to stand down on the comparison thing, and let Roberto show his inborn talent. Indeed, the kind of voice he has, and the acting prowess he projects is not learned. His is a powerfully moving break down,... his "Vesti". You'd have to have a heart of stone to not feel moved. Congratulations , Roberto Alagna on another wonderful interpretation of.One last small remark - I have also heard others feel let down by the set in other operas. The really great one with Edita Gruberova and many other well loved vocalists who starred with her in "I Puritani", was not helped by the starkness, and poor lighting of that set. This is the set designer's job, of course - but honestly and truly, it  can be a clammy, cold, wet blanket on  an otherwise fabulous performance. This is critical , producers...choose your set designer very, very carefully. This set for this Pagliacci is one of those unneccessarily gloomy, hard as rock sets. Indeed...it's All rock,this set, isn't it? Are we to think that everyone in the past lived in something like dungeons above ground? Other than that...I would go for this version. If for no other reason than to have some copies of Alagna's performances before he became a household word.He is terrific; and so are all the others starring with him. The audience?...what a cold, clammy, dull as river stone  audience...that didn't help either. It's almost like someone had to send a mild electric shock through their seats and wake them up, and make them do something...like applaud, for the love of God.
Title: Leoncavallo - Pagliacci

reviewText: This is the first production of Pagliacci that I have seen or heard. Beyond hearing the beautiful aria "Vesti la guibba", I was not familiar with this opera. This is a first rate performance with a fantastic cast. Roberto Alagna really sings his heart out and puts his soul into being Pagliacci. His character's moods are mercurial and dark. Alagna's version of "Vesti" is heartbreaking. He is also an excellent actor. Vassileva is a fine soprano, good actress and extremely beautiful. However, I found her voice to be rather chilly which probably worked well in conveying her character's cold-heartedness. I highly recommend this opera. I think anyone that has been rejected or dumped can sympathize with Pagliacci's plight. The theme of rejection and revenge strikes a chord with all of us.
Title: Leoncavallo - Pagliacci

reviewText: I've seen and heard a lot of Pagliaccis, and this will always remain one of my favorites, and one I would recommend to you.Here's why:There is excellent singing and absolutely the best acting I've ever seen in a Pagliacci.  Roberto Alagna's "Vesti la giubba," even though I was prepared for it, was so strong and most passionate that it brought tears to my eyes.Tonio (Alberto Mastromarino) walks and sings with an appropriate dull-witted heaviness that makings him all the more menacing as he sets into motion the jealousy that consumes Canio, Nedda, and Silvio.Nedda (Svetla Vassileva) not only acts the part of a woman controlled by her passions, she also has a very lovely voice, and is so beautiful that it's easy to see why Canio is wary of losing her.The staging:  scenery, costumes, and lighting make the audience feel we are right there in a small town in Italy, sometime between 1880  and 1920, experiencing what is really happening right now on stage, and that's what "teatro verismo" is all about.  This is a Pagliacci you will want to share with friends!
Title: Leoncavallo - Pagliacci

reviewText: I Netflix'd this performance and boy, am I glad.  Produced and designed by Robert Alagna's two brothers this production looks interesting on the surface but has absolutely no substance.First the singing.  I have a great admiration for Roberto Alagna's voice and technique. He sings the role well enough but he's making a personal appearance in Leoncavallo's 'Pagliacci' not playing the role of Canio.  He's so virile and bouncing about the stage you can't imagine why Nedda would have a wandering eye. Svetla Vassileva has a decent soprano that really only has any weight on the top of the voice. Her trills in the Ballatella are approximate and I get the impression that with a stronger director there's a good if not great performance there.  She doesn't appear to have been given much motivation and there's a lack of intensity in the finale because of that.The Tonio of Alberto Mastromarino is a bit better presented. A solid Prologue and it's a shame that's the most singing the character does all night.  But one of the strangest things about this whole train wreck is the Silvio of Enrico Marruci who, in a bizarre twist, is less attractive than the Tonio, the character who's supposed to be repulsive. In close up Mr. Marruci is covered with moles and/or acne that they're trying to hide under a lot of makeup.  Why anyone would choose this wan slip of a youth when you've got Mr. Alagna still bouncing about is ridiculous.Which goes to the heart of the big problem with this production.  It only looks good. Also, it looks good but with no reason for how it looks.  The entire village is only wearing black and white.  Nedda wears a black leather pants suit in the first scene.  What ?  Canio puts on a full-length white trench coat after 'Vesti la Giubba' with a clown ruffle around the lapel and cuffs.  It looks slimming on him but, huh ?  Then it appears at the finale ( spoiler ) Silvio stabs Canio as well,  which I don't mind but it's a little ambiguous in the staging and I'm still not sure after watching it twice. I could go on and on with details that are lacking and or wrong in the context of the work.  The en masse choreography for the chorus. Everyone's hands in the air and clap, clap, clap. It's verismo.The sets are ugly. Period.  The staging is inept and it looks like the Brothers Alagna have some slick ideas but have no knowledge of commedia del'arte tradition or characters.  Nor do they have any kind of grasp on native village life in Italy.  The whole chorus hot foot's it into the wings at the finale ( what Italian wouldn't stay for a knife fight ? ) so that Mr. Alagna can have the entire stage to himself at the curtain drop.  A total lack of verisimilitude in a verismo opera.  The real tragedy in this story isn't Nedda's betrayal and Canio's foul temper but how someone managed to entrust this great work to a pair of amateur producers who know not what they do.The Zeffirelli film with Domingo and Stratas is classic and comes with a very good 'Cavalaria Rusticana' as well.  Unless your an Alagna junkie there's absolutely no point in spending money on this misguided vanity vehicle.
Title: Leoncavallo - Pagliacci
